message: Here's something from their page: http://us.pycon.org/2011/venue/restaurants/

Depends on where you're coming from and if you have a car and what you want to eat.  Peachtree Street has lots of places to eat, including the ones mentioned on the site.  Further up Peachtree, there's Ted's (as in Turner) if you like eating bison and R. Thomas if you're a vegetarian.
Anybody hungry for Wed. evening?
Ate at Ted's on Luckie tonight and Abbatoir http://www.starprovisions.com/ last night. It was very good.
A visit to Soul Veg. is a must for anyone who likes vegetarian and vegan foods. There is one easy to get to via Marta.
Went to Holeman & Finch http://holeman-finch.com/ last year. It begs a repeat visit this year.
Other Candidates for this year are EMpire State South http://is.gd/zDZOK6, Peter Chang's http://is.gd/BFo3hP and La Pietra Cucina http://is.gd/ty2WHh if anyone is interested in going @ me
@gpshead Any plans for a trip? I missed Soul Veg last year
Ted's verdict: Food 4/5, Service 4/5, Wine 5/5. I was quite impressed with their wine selection.
Gladys (as in Knight) and Ron's Chicken and Waffles is an icon. And not too far down Peachtree from the Hyatt. http://gladysandron.net/
And for a crazy-good beer selection, Taco Mac Metropolis http://twitter.com/#!/Tmacmetropolis
that's http://twitter.com/Tmacmetropolis
Django (http://djangoatlanta.com) for obvious reasons, but I heard the food was good.  There's also a Chick-Fil-A in the basement =)
Taco Mac is awesome

Bacchanalia http://www.starprovisions.com/ is consistently in the running for best fine dining (typically #1 in the Zagat guide) if you're looking for a fancy night out. Be forewarned that dinner (sans drinks) is $85 a plate.
For bar info, check the official PyCon page http://us.pycon.org/2011/venue/bars/ and the convore topic about a potential pubcrawl https://convore.com/pycon-2011/pub-crawl-for-first-timers-and-non/

+1 Taco Mac in Midtown. Take MARTA train near hotel from Peachtree to Midtown, walk two blocks east to Peachtree and it's right there. Google Maps w/transit info: http://is.gd/jLqVGS The spicy black bean spinach wrap was very tasty, over 100 beers on draught, great service, pool tables, Euro Champions match on HDTV Tottenham v. AC Milan and pretty much every other sport except curling.
Beer fans should definitely try The Brick Store Pub http://www.brickstorepub.com/
For slightly more Americanized asian, try http://www.grandchinaatl.com/ for Chinese and http://www.malirestaurant.com/ for Thai.

For sushi, http://www.genkiatl.com/ http://mfsushibar.com/ and http://www.takasushiatlanta.com/ are all highly respected. I've been to Taka, and it is outstanding. If you're willing to travel well up Buford highway (to the duluth area, basically), you can find lots of very authentic Asian (and Latin American) places (as in, none of the signage is even in English).
For fans of Top Chef, Kevin Gillespie from Season 6 is a local. Check out his cuisine at http://www.woodfiregrill.com/
Papi's cuban sandwitch/burger/sucos is awesome! it's on pance de leone and myrtle, about 20 minute walk from conference
I'm tentatively planning on trekking to soul vegetarian tomorrow evening for dinner, @ me if interested
How about some BoF posts in this vein? Maybe put together a dinner party or two?

had a good meal at the vortex tonight down in little five points. great drinks, burgers, sweet potato fries, etc. in a funky, eclectic environment. i definitely recommend checking out the little five points area. lots of cool shops, bars, tatoo/piercing places and culture. reminds me of south street, philly. check it out if you want to get out of the downtown, corporate vibe.

Bunch of us had a big pile of sushi at Pacific Rim Bistro around the corner from the hotel.  Not the greatest, but certainly not the worst I've ever had.  Can't beat it for proximity!  Decent wine list, but wish they had more sake options.
If anyone is here on a tight budget, I happened upon the Landmark Diner tonight. The food was pretty good and my dinner was under $10.
check out Thrive for really upscale....sushi is on the menu
Mary Mac's Tea Room - really good southern food and hospitality. We took MARTA two stops plus a few minute walk, but walked all the way back.
did the Landmark Diner several times last year, I second the recommendation.
The diner is also 24 hours... great for those arriving on a late flight.
My AirBnB host recommended this place: http://www.yelp.com/biz/fellinis-pizza-atlanta
The locals at Manuel's last night highly recommended Decatur as a great nightspot for dining and pub crawling.
Downtown Decatur has has some great stuff and is easy to get to from Marta
yay for brick store pub!
Looks good: http://www.brickstorepub.com/home/ 1 block from MARTA. Locals mentioned it as one of the better spots in Decatur.
See also the pub crawl topic and the bars page on the pycon site.
Iberian Pig has great Spanish food and wine, in Decatur near Brick Store Pub (great beer selection, lots of Belgians... beers that is)
Sounds like Decatur is the happenin' spot
There are lots of good places in Decatur. I really like Noodle... It's an Asian Fusion kinda place... their Pho Ga is amazing.
Mary Macs is a classic 'old school' Atlanta restaurant. I haven't been there in years though, so I don't know what the quality's like currently.
Chick-Fil-A.  That is all.

btw, opted not to go to Soul Veg sunday night due to their reported defacing of a library in DC with muslim hate posters.  I didn't look up to see if it was true given that they're already known as quite a cult... easier to just take business elsewhere.
mellow_mushroom == "Good Pizza and Beer"
True
